Ask HN: How do you avoid getting lost in the lessons learned from experiments?
text:
If you've used validated learning or an experimental approach for your projects. How have you managed them and kept track of the learning learned along the way, without getting lost in the sheer amount of experiments and learning?

I'm quickly getting lost in the experiments across multiple facets of my business, and would love some insights into how you guys are continually learning as a business.

Cheers

title: Ask HN: Fully Functional Xilinx Vivado on Arch Linux?
text:
Currently I have a separate Ubuntu partition just for Vivado and it would be really convenient if I could use it with my main distro, Arch Linux.

I think that installing it directly on Arch would not be very wise from a stability point of view (and it requires some intervention to even install anyway), so I tried creating a systemd-nspawn container with Ubuntu in it. I could launch the Vivado GUI and generate a bitstream for a project easily this way (thank you, ArchWiki), but the hardware server would not recognize the board plugged in via USB. This was a few months ago but now I want to use Vivado again and a lot.

Ideally I would like some advice on getting Vivado to properly interact with hardware from inside the container, if possible, but any advice on how people deal with Vivado's tight OS requirements (besides sucking it up) would be appreciated.

Ask HN: Why did Twitter put content warnings on all my tweets?
text:
My Twitter account has 10 followers, several of which I know personally. I follow a tiny number of people. All my tweets are unremarkable. Can anyone at Twitter look into this?

My Twitter handle is @FamilialRhino. Thanks.

PS: What is weird is that the warnings don't show when my wife looks at my tweets, but they are displayed when I log in as @FamilialRhino. I already appealed several warnings, but gave up when I noticed that all my posts are flagged. What gives?
